newsitem.title: BURMA: Burmese general urges people to crush traitors.
newsitem.headline: Burmese general urges people to crush traitors.

text.p: One of Burma's most powerful generals has urged patriotic Burmese to crush "axe-handles" or traitors who are spreading Western ideals throughout the country, official media reported on Monday.

"I would like to urge all those who love the nation to crush axe-handles who are acting to the liking of neo-colonialists and spreading Western ideals for domination of western culture," state-run media quoted military intelligence chief, Lieutenant General Khin Nyunt, as saying.
Khin Nyunt, who is also Secretary One of the ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council (SLORC), made the remarks in a speech.

Burmese officials have repeatedly called democracy leader and Nobel Peace laureate Aung San Suu Kyi an "axe handle" and accused her of colluding with Western nations, especially the United States, to create instability and unrest in the country.
"Neo-colonialism today has its way of breeding their cohorts in a country they want to get under their influence and try to dominate it with their cultural ways," he said.

"Today too, it is found that there are stooges and axe handles reared by neo-colonialists trying to dim and obliterate Myanmar culture, traditions and customs to enslave Myanmar people again, not only just to make the world look down on Myanmar," he said.
Myanmar is what the SLORC renamed Burma after it seized power in 1988.
Roadblocks manned by heavily-armed security police barring access to Suu Kyi's street remained in place on Monday for the 10th consecutive day.
The government has said it set up the barricades to prevent unrest.

The blockades, which were also in place from September 26 to October 8 to stop Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy Party (NLD) from holding a party congress in late September, prevented Suu Kyi from holding regular weekend speeches to supporters for the fourth weekend in a row.
The government also arrested 573 democracy activists in late September but later released them in stages.
